unnormalised: Booking travel and hotels in India requires a familiarity with the diverse ways Indian addresses are formatted. Unlike standardized address formats in some Western countries, Indian addresses can vary significantly based on region, city planning, and even personal preference. This guide aims to provide a basic understanding to help you navigate the complexities of Indian addresses when making travel arrangements. Knowing how to decipher these addresses can prevent delays and ensure smooth check-ins.

unnormalised: One common structure includes the house number, building name (if applicable), street name, area or locality, city, state, and postal code (PIN code). For example, a hypothetical address could look like this: "Flat No. 201, Krishna Apartments, Nehru Road, Bandra West, Mumbai, Maharashtra, 400050". Notice the use of "Flat No." instead of "Apartment" and the inclusion of "Bandra West" to specify the locality. The PIN code is crucial for postal services and should always be included when available. Variations might include adding a landmark near the address for easier identification.
normalised: One common structure includes the house number, building name (if applicable), street name, area or locality, city, state, and postal code (P-I-N code). For example, a hypothetical address could look like this: "Flat Number two hundred and one, Krishna Apartments, Nehru Road, Bandra West, Mumbai, Maharashtra, four hundred thousand and fifty". Notice the use of "Flat Number" instead of "Apartment" and the inclusion of "Bandra West" to specify the locality. The P-I-N code is crucial for postal services and should always be included when available. Variations might include adding a landmark near the address for easier identification.

unnormalised: Rural addresses often differ. They may not have a house number or street name, relying instead on village names and post office details. An example might be: "C/o Rakesh Sharma, Near Panchayat Office, Village Rampur, Post Office: Sohna, Haryana, 122103". "C/o" stands for "care of," indicating the intended recipient within the village. It's essential to include the Post Office (PO) name as mail is often sorted there. The PIN code is equally vital in rural areas for accurate delivery.

unnormalised: When booking hotels, be sure to carefully check the address provided. Many hotels list their address as "Hotel XYZ, Opp. ABC Mall, MG Road, Bangalore, 560001". "Opp." is a common abbreviation for "opposite". Double-check the full address and contact details on the hotel's official website or booking confirmation to avoid any ambiguity. Using online map services with the full address, including the PIN code, can also help visualize the location.

Always confirm the complete address with the hotel or travel provider and use reliable mapping tools to ensure you’re heading to the right location. Being mindful of these nuances will contribute to a more pleasant and efficient travel experience within India.
